params.name: options
params.doc: Options for creating an external database connection.

ret.doc: Details of external database connection created.

docs.summary: Creates a new external database connection.
description:
The `externalDatabaseConnection` parameter must include a `name`, `endpoint`, and `configuration` details for the external database.
If any of these are missing, the external database connection isn't created.

examples.title: Create an external database connection (dashboard page code)
body: console.log('Successfully created an external database connection. Full response:', createExternalDbConnectionResponse);

examples.title: Create an external database connection (export from backend code)
body: console.log('Successfully created an external database connection. Full response:', createExternalDbConnectionResponse);

params.name: name
params.doc: Name of the external database connection to delete.

description: > **Note:** Once an external database connection is deleted, it can't be restored. To reconnect the database you need to create a new external database connection.

examples.title: Delete an external database connection (dashboard page code)
Delete an external database connection (export from backend code)

params.name: name
params.doc: Name of the external database connection to retrieve.

ret.doc: Details of the external database connection requested.

docs.summary: Retrieves an external database connection by name.

examples.title: Get an external database connection (dashboard page code)
body: console.log(`Retrieved the ${name} external database connection, which is ${connectionSuccessful ? 'successful' : 'unsuccessful'}`);

examples.title: Get an external database connection (export from backend code)
body: console.log(`Retrieved the ${name} external database connection, which is ${connectionSuccessful ? 'successful' : 'unsuccessful'}`);

docs.summary: Retrieves a list of all external database collections associated with the site or project.

examples.title: List existing external database connections (dashboard page code)
body: console.log('Here is a list of all current external database connections: ', listExternalDbConnectionsResponse.externalDatabaseConnections);

examples.title: List existing external database connections (export from backend code)
body: console.log('Here is a list of all current external database connections: ', listExternalDbConnectionsResponse.externalDatabaseConnections);

examples.title: List existing external database connections with pagination
body: console.log('Here is a list of all current external database connections: ', listExternalDbConnectionsResponse.externalDatabaseConnections);

params.name: name
params.doc:
Name of the external database connection.
An external database connection may connect to one or more external data collections or tables.
These are represented as `connectionName/dataCollectionId`.

params.name: externalDatabaseConnection
params.doc: Updated external database connection details. The existing connection is replaced with this version.

description:
An external database collection name must be provided in `name`.
If an existing external database connection is found with the same name, that connection's details are updated.
If no external database connection has that name, the request fails.

> **Note:** After an external database connection is updated, it only contains the values provided in the request. All previous values are lost.

examples.title: Update an existing external database connection (dashboard page code)
body: console.log(`The ${name} connection was updated with the new values. It is currently mounted at ${updateExternalDatabaseConnectionResponse.endpoint}`);

examples.title: Update an existing external database connection (export from backend code)
body: console.log(`The ${name} connection was updated with the new values. It is currently mounted at ${updateExternalDatabaseConnectionResponse.endpoint}`);

members.name: collectionModificationsSupported
members.doc: Whether the external database supports creating new collections, updating the structure of existing collections, or deleting them.

members.name: fieldTypes
members.doc:
Field types the external database supports.
This field only applies when `collectionModificationsSupported` is `true`.

members.name: causeOfFailure
members.doc:
If and why a connection attempt failed.
+ `NONE`: No connection failure.
+ `COMMUNICATION_FAILURE`: General communication failure.
+ `DESTINATION_HOST_UNREACHABLE`: External database host is unreachable.
+ `UNAUTHORIZED`: Unauthorized to access external database.
+ `DESTINATION_ENDPOINT_NOT_DEFINED`: `Endpoint` property is not set.

members.name: hasCollections
members.doc:
Whether the external database has existing collections. Possible values are:
+ `UNKNOWN`: The attempt to connect to the external database failed, so status is unknown.
+ `NO`: External database does not have any existing collections.
+ `YES`: External database has existing collections.

members.name: successful
members.doc: Whether the connection was established successfully.

members.name: connectionType
members.doc: Connection type.

members.name: connectionType
members.doc: Connection type.

members.name: externalDatabaseConnection
members.doc: External database connection details.

members.name: externalDatabaseConnection
members.doc: Details of external database connection created.

members.name: name
members.doc: Name of the external database connection to delete.

members.name: _id
members.doc:
Unique event ID.
Allows clients to ignore duplicate webhooks.

members.name: entityEventSequence
members.doc:
A sequence number defining the order of updates to the underlying entity.
For example, given that some entity was updated at 16:00 and than again at 16:01,
it is guaranteed that the sequence number of the second update is strictly higher than the first.
As the consumer, you can use this value to ensure that you handle messages in the correct order.
To do so, you will need to persist this number on your end, and compare the sequence number from the
message against the one you have stored. Given that the stored number is higher, you should ignore the message.

members.name: entityFqdn
members.doc:
Assumes actions are also always typed to an entity_type
Example: wix.stores.catalog.product, wix.bookings.session, wix.payments.transaction

members.name: entityId
members.doc: ID of the entity associated with the event.

members.name: eventTime
members.doc: Event timestamp.

members.name: originatedFrom
members.doc: If present, indicates the action that triggered the event.

members.name: slug
members.doc:
This is top level to ease client code dispatching of messages (switch on entity_fqdn+slug)
This is although the created/updated/deleted notion is duplication of the oneof types
Example: created/updated/deleted/started/completed/email_opened

members.name: triggeredByAnonymizeRequest
members.doc:
Whether the event was triggered as a result of a privacy regulation application
(for example, GDPR).

members.name: deletedEntityAsJson
members.doc: Entity that was deleted

members.name: currentEntityAsJson
members.doc:
Since platformized APIs only expose PATCH and not PUT we can't assume that the fields sent from the client are the actual diff.
This means that to generate a list of changed fields (as opposed to sent fields) one needs to traverse both objects.
We don't want to impose this on all developers and so we leave this traversal to the notification recipients which need it.

members.name: capabilities
members.doc: The external database's capabilities.

members.name: configuration
members.doc:
Settings passed to the external database connection as part of each request.
These settings can relate to authentication, tenancy, or provide any other information needed for processing a request.
Their content and structure depend on the specific requirements of the external database's API.

members.name: connectionStatus
members.doc: Status of the external database connection. Includes whether the connection was established successfully, and if not, the reason for the failure.

members.name: endpoint
members.doc: Base URL for provisioning and managing data in the external database. For example: `https://example.com/my-external-database`.

members.name: name
members.doc:
Name of the external database connection.
An external database connection may connect to one or more external data collections or tables.
These are represented as `connectionName/dataCollectionId`.

description: An external database connection defines a connection between an external database and a Wix site or project.

members.name: offset

members.name: count
members.doc: Number of items returned in the response.

members.name: offset
members.doc: Offset that was requested.

members.name: tooManyToCount
members.doc: Flag that indicates the server failed to calculate the `total` field.

members.name: total
members.doc: Total number of items that match the query.
